message: Ok this is giving me headaches for quite a while now. Imagine you have a paginated ListView of News objects. So you browse through the list and end up on "/news/?page=2". You find an interesting news and click at the "More" link in order to see it's DetailsView. After reading the whole news you want to get back to the list and you want to be at page=2 again. How can this be done?

Hmm I just had a look at how wordpress does this. There doesn't seem to be any back-link, forcing the user to use the browers back button, which is the cleanest and best solution anyways. I guess I will do the same :)
I really hate the back button. It encourages people to build lame-assed navigation structures and let users view outdated information. </soapbox>
You mean the back button of the browser or the back link in a webpage?

If you *really* had to have this feature, you could always create an aggregate query based on a known order_by to determine how many model instances would appear before the current one, then determine page number based on known page size. (I don't at all recommend this approach. This is what the browser back button is for.)
@holdenweb

@dgouldin yep this is what I came up with as well then brainstorming this problem. However I am afraid that this will make the page very slow once there are many many News objects in the database. Thanks for the suggestion! I think that is the best approach if you * really* want to have that back-link...
@mbrochh agreed, no need to make your database cry to duplicate a feature browsers have supported natively for a long long time.

I just did this for a member directory on a project recently. I saved the full request path (including the page parameter or any search filter) to the user's session before displaying the listing page. Then in the profile template I check to see if that session variable exists, pointing the back link to there if it does; if it doesn't the link goes to the first page of the listing.
https://gist.github.com/886414

@coderanger you could create a unique token to avoid tab issues, but then you'd be polluting the session, probably better stored in cache with a very limited expiration. Still, best not to get into that business. ;)

I get asked to make it so people can return to their filtered changelists after editing something, and I haven't really been able to come up with a good solution besides trying to convince people to use tabs more
One option is to use the History API to fake the whole thing
The history API idea is really good, I think
The downside is not all browsers support it well, though going back to the first page as a fallback isn't the end of the world
Right, it already works without JavaScript, so it would degrade gracefully as long as nothing is broken in the process of also making it AJAXy
Also unsure about how hard it would be to do a full-page replacement via AJAX, though if you can just swap out the content div (assuming all CSS is shared, etc) then that isn't so bad
You never actually change page context, so you can keep the address of the original around in JS
@dryan That approach doesn't work well with having multiple tabs open usually.
@dryan that breaks if the list changes between storing in the session and displaying to the user. Better to give no answer than the wrong answer IMO.
I can see that working with the Admin when going from a changelist to an individual record
Devil's in the details, I guess
And the form submission needs to be intercepted
@ramen I assume both sides would just be links, easy enough to setup click handlers using jQuery.live
Could you not use HTTP referrer if it was there? Revert to something else if not.
@dgouldin I can see that. I think in my case there's not really an issue there.
